column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=The potential for automation has been a key driving factor in the development of the interconnection process since automation is essential for large scale production of the fabric/garment.
#Text=Also, automation is preferred for the reproducibility and repeatability of the various steps to create a uniform product on a continuous basis.
#Text=The details of the various steps are presently discussed.
#Text=1.
#Text=Softening and Removal of Insulation
#Text=In order to make a connection of intersecting electrical conductive fibers, the insulation at the intersection must first be removed.
#Text=This can be done by any one of a number of ways.

#Text=Suitable removable techniques include chemical etching, mechanical removal and any spot welding technique such as ultrasonic welding, laser light application or other localized heating technique.
#Text=Preferably, the interconnection zone is chemically softened for the effective removal of the insulation, such as vinyl sheath.
#Text=The process variables are: (i) the chemical used in the process; (ii) the concentration of the chemical; (iii) the amount of chemical applied; and (iv) duration of chemical application.
#Text=Acetone has been found to work quite well as a chemical-softening agent.
#Text=A few drops of Acetone are applied.
#Text=It is allowed to stand for about 10 seconds before the next step in the process.
#Text=These processing conditions ensure that the conductive yarn itself is not damaged.
#Text=Also since polyester, cotton and SPANDEX do not interact with acetone, they are not damaged during this process.
#Text=Where stainless steel is used as the electrical conductive fiber, heat alone may be sufficient to achieve the desired softening and removal of insulation.
#Text=2.
#Text=Abrasion of Insulation
#Text=The next step, if needed, is to abrade the insulation at the intersection zone that has been softened.
#Text=A vibrating brush can be used, preferably one that oscillates at 3000 Hz.
#Text=This effectively strips out the insulation at the interconnection zone as shown in FIG. 9.
#Text=The process variables are: (i) the frequency of oscillation of the brush; (ii) the pressure applied during abrasion; and (iii) duration of abrasion.
#Text=By modifying these parameters, it would be possible to strip out different types of insulation without damaging the conductive yarns themselves.
#Text=Depending on the method used for removal of insulation, it may or may not be necessary to carry out this step.
#Text=Some methods of removal may result in removal of sufficient amount of insulation such that this abrasion step would not be needed.
